Title: Erratum to “Brief interventions to prevent sexually transmitted infections suitable for in-service use: A systematic review” [Prev. Med. (2016) 91 364–382] (S0091743516301633)(10.1016/j.ypmed.2016.06.038)
Abstract: © 2016The authors would like to provide a few changes in the published article mentioned above. In Section 2.4, please read paragraph 2, line 8 as “Supplementary document D”… Table 2: Summary table for young people studies. Shrier (2001) Intervention: video and one-to-one counselling. Follow-up: 1, 3, 6, 12 months Table 3: Summary table for MSM studies. Milam (2014) Setting: online (USA) Table 4: Summary of effective and ineffective trials for outcomes of interest. In fourth column it should be read as “No. of trials” In third column ‘Outcome’ and in the row ‘Delivery format - Digital’, read STI-test as STI testing. In third column ‘Outcome’, and in the row ‘Delivery format - One-to-one counselling’, read STI-test as STI testing. In third column ‘Outcome’, and in the row ‘Delivery format – Video’, read STI-test as STI testing. In third column ‘Outcome’, and in the row ‘Delivery format - Home test kit’, read STI-test as STI testing. In seventh column ‘Outcome’, and in the row ‘Delivery format One-to-one counselling’, read STI-test as STI testing. In seventh column ‘Outcome’, and in the row ‘Delivery format Video’, read STI-test as STI testing. In twelfth column ‘Outcome’, and in the row ‘Delivery format Digital’, read STI-test as STI testing. In twelfth column ‘Outcome’, and in the row ‘Delivery format One-to-one counselling’, read STI-test as STI testing. In sixteenth column ‘Outcome’ and in the row ‘Delivery format Digital’, read STI-test as STI testing. Changes in the captions of Table 4: “Abbreviations: Behavior (risky sexual behaviour); STI-testing (STI test uptake); STIs (incidence of STIs); Info (any kind of information); NormA (Normative Arguments); AttA (Attitudinal Arguments); SkillA (Behavioral Skills Arguments); ThreatA (Threat inducing Arguments); Condomtrain (Condom Use Skills Training); Condom (condom provision), PersonTrain (Interpersonal Skills Training); SelfMan (Self-Management Training); STI-test (STI/HIV Counselling and Testing)”. Section 4.1 (Limitations and strengths of this review) In paragraph 1, line 6, please read the PROSPERO text as follows: PROSPERO protocol registration number “CRD42014014375”. Paragraph 4, line 5, please read the corrected sentence as: “For example, 16 of 23 trials involving young people and all of those involving MSM were conducted in the USA.” In Section 3.1.1.3, paragraph 3, line 4, the below sentence has been added: “Both ineffective digital interventions included provision of information.” In Section 3.1.2.2, please read the line 1 as follows: “One of six online web-based interventions for MSM was found to be effective for increasing STI test uptake.” Discussion In paragraph 1, please read the first line as follows: “This review has identified a small number of effective interventions (15 for young people and eight for MSM) suitable for in-service delivery in sexual health clinics that reduced STIs among young people, increased STI testing and reduced STI-risk behaviors among young people and MSM.” In paragraph 1, please read the line 8 as follows: “Effective interventions, across outcomes, included one-to-one counselling, video presentations, digital offline computer software and online web-based interventions including use of social media.” In Section 4.2 (Implications for research and practice), in paragraph 2, please read the first line as follows: “For young people, two of seven studies involving one-to-one counselling (involving 2 × 20 min sessions) (Bolu et al., 2004; Gottlieb et al., 2004), one study involving counseling and a swab test (Apoola and Brunt, 2011), one study involving a digital (email) intervention (Kang et al., 2012) and all three studies involving home STI test kits (Cook et al., 2007; Ostergaard et al., 2000; Scholes et al., 2007) were found to be effective for reducing STI rates or increasing STI testing. One of two studies involving offline digital interventions (Klein and Card, 2011), two of three online web-based interventions (Bull et al., 2012; Mevissen et al., 2011) and one of two interventions involving printed materials (Scholes et al., 2003) were found to be effective for reducing self-reported sexual risk behavior patterns in young people.” Updated references are given below: “Dermen, K.H., Thomas, S.N., 2011. Randomized controlled trial of brief interventions to reduce college students' drinking and risky sex. Psychol. Addict. Behav. 25 (4), 583-594.” “Dilley, J.W., Woods, W.J., Sabatino, J., Lihatsh, T., Adler, B., Casey, S., et al., 2002. Changing sexual behavior among gay male repeat testers for HIV: a randomized, controlled trial of a single-session intervention. J. Acquir. Immune Defic. Syndr. 30 (2), 177–186.” “Global incidence and prevalence of selected curable sexually transmitted infections. In: WHO (Ed.), Research (2008).” “Herbst, J.H., Beeker, C., Mathew, A., McNally, T., Passin, W.F., Kay, L.S., et al., 2007. The effectiveness of individual-, group-, and community-level HIV behavioral risk-reduction interventions for adult men who have sex with men: a systematic review. Am. J. Prev. Med. 32 (4 Suppl.), S38–S67.” “Scholes, D., Heidrich, F.E., Yarbro, P., Lindenbaum, J.E., Marrazzo, J.M., 2007. Population-based outreach for Chlamydia screening in men: results from a randomized trial. Sex. Transm. Dis. 34 (11), 837–839.” “Sikkema, K.J., Abler, L., Hansen, N.B., Wilson, P.A., Drabkin, A.S., Kochman, A., et al., 2014. Positive choices: outcomes of a brief risk reduction intervention for newly HIV-diagnosed men who have sex with men. AIDS Behav. 18 (9),1808–1819.” “Wolitski, R.J., Parsons, J.T., Gomez, C.A., Purcell, D.W., Hoff, C.C., Halkitis, P.N., 2005. Prevention with gay and bisexual men living with HIV: rationale and methods of the Seropositive Urban Men's Intervention Trial (SUMIT). AIDS 19 (Suppl 1), S1–S11.”
